bibl.title: Military Orders regarding Columbia Barracks, June 9, 1900

div1.p: Stark responds with a facetious remark to a request for carbolic acid for sanitary purposes at Columbia Barracks. Endorsements are dated June 9 to June 15, 1900. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders regarding Columbia Barracks, June 9, 1900
div1.p:
Col Bk, Havana, Cuba.
RECEIVED JUN 9 1900

Comdg. Officer
Li.. Art. Bat.

Requests to be furnished
with disinfectants unclear
gives reason

June, 10, 1900
To Surgeon, for report.
To be returned as soon as practi-
cable.
1st Endorsement.

Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks,
Cuba, June 11, 1900.

Respectfully returned to the Adjutant
with the remark that this communication
displays a woeful lack of sanitary
knowledge.

The sprinkling of carbolic acid on
floors and in sinks is as futile to ward
off disease as the effort of the builders
of the Tower of Babel to reach Heaven.

If was kitchens and sinks require a
deodorizer like carbolic acid then it is high
time that soap and water are brought in-
to use.

The Chief Surgeon has not disapproved
of any requisition for disinfectants in
the knowledge of the Surgeon, but on the
contrary has facilitated the procuring
of everything asked for. The Post San-
itary Officer is correct in stating that he cannot
get disinfectants for casting broadcast
DR. 82 L.A.B.
1900
about the reservation. The Sur-
geon has an abundance of disin-
fectants, but their routine use
is a reproach upon the sanitary
police of the post and is not
therefore permissible -(See A. R.
1462).

No infection exists in the post
at present and stronger measures
than an attempt to froighten Yel-
low Fever with a little carbolic
acid will be necessary to prevent
its introduction.

If the Light Arty Battalion
will keep its kitchens and sinks
aesthetically clean and the bed-
ding and clothes properly aired
and sunned, the Surgeon will take
care of the Yellow Fever.
A. N. Stark,

Capt. & Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Surgeon.
JUN 11 Rec'd L.R. 1617.

6/11. 1900.
To. C.O.
Light Arty Bat, 2nd Army

2d Endorsements
Light Artillery Battalion
Columbia Barracks, Cuba
June 13 1900
Respectfully returned to the
adjutants Columbia Barracks
Cuba. The endorsements of
Surgeon A. M. Stark U.S.A.
I consider discourteous and
in direct violation of par
4. A.R. I am still of the
opinion that the use of a
solution of carbolic acid
about the kitchens, sinks,
slop cans and wet places will
prevent the gathering of
flies. For this purpose
the acid is desired.

R. R. Roberts
Major 2d Artillery.
Comd'g Battalion.
L.R. 1690
Jun 13 Ent'd

4th. Endorsement.
HEADQUARTERS COLUMBIA BARRACKS.
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.
June, 14, 1900.

Respectfully referred to the
Surgeon, Columbia Barracks,
attention invited to the 2nd. en-
dorsement hereon, which is con-
curred in. The Surgeon's face-
tious remarks in the 1st. endor-
sement are not approved of, and
will not be permitted in the fu-
ture.
This paper to be returned.
BY ORDER OF COLONEL BALDWIN.

Capt. & Adjt. 7th Cavalry
Adjutant.

5th Endorsement.
Post Hospital, Columbia bks.,
Cuba, June 15, 1900.
Respectfully returned to
the Adjutant, Culumbia Barrack.
Contents noted.

A.N. Stark,
Capt. & Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Surgeon.
L.S

div1.head: Letter from R. K. Roberts to the Adjutant General, June 9, 1900
div1.opener:
msce letter received Dept of
Cuba 1900-1901
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
File under Stark
Light Artillery Battalion
Columbia Barracks Cuba.
June 9, 1900
The Adjutant
Columbia Barracks. Cuba.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I respectfully request than I may be furnished
with a supply of carbolic acid and three watering pots
for sanitary purposes about the bathing kitchens, water
closets, officer closets and kitchens. I have applied to
Act Asst. Surgeon De Poorter Jr. Sanitary Officer, for a
supply of disinfectants, for the purposes stated, and was
informed by him that he could not supply it; that he
had required for a quantity of carbolic acid for this
purpose but that his requisition had met with dis-
approval by the Chief Surgeon of the Department.

The Post Quartermaster informs me that he cannot
supply the acid. I request that this matter be brought
to the attention of the Department Commander.

In my opinion this, or some as effective disinfectant,
should be furnished for my battalion for the purposes
stated, especially so, while yellow fever is near at hand
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, R. K. Roberts. Major 2d Artillery.
Comdg. Battalion
To be held until report ⟨L.R. 1585⟩ is returned from Surgeon
